{"id":38,"value":"lightshow","label":"Lightshow","cardTypes":[1],"details":[["This keyword represents X-Men using fireworks and blinding bursts in spectacular combinations."],{"points":[["Some Heroes say things like \u201c",{"bold":"Lightshow:"}," You get ",{"bold":"+3"},{"icon":1},".\u201d ",{"bold":" Once per turn, if you played at least two Lightshow cards this turn, you can use a single Lightshow ability from any of those cards."}],["If you play three, four, or more Lightshow cards you still use only a single Lightshow ability."]]}],"_id":"063PI2p73uc6zgtY","detailsOutput":"This keyword represents X-Men using fireworks and blinding bursts in spectacular combinations.
  • Some Heroes say things like \u201cLightshow:<\/strong> You get +3<\/strong>.\u201d Once per turn, if you played at least two Lightshow cards this turn, you can use a single Lightshow ability from any of those cards.<\/strong><\/li>
  • If you play three, four, or more Lightshow cards you still use only a single Lightshow ability.<\/li><\/ul>"}

{"id":69,"value":"whenrecruited","label":"\u201cWhen Recruited\u201c Abilities","sortLabel":"When Recruited Abilities","cardTypes":[1],"details":[["The Inhumans' powerful decision to go to war is shown with new special abilities they use \u201cWhen Recruited.\u201c"],{"points":[["Some Heroes say things like: \u201cWhen Recruited: You get ",{"bold":"+3"},{"icon":1},".\u201c ",{"bold":"Use this \u201cWhen Recruited\u201c ability immediately when you recruit this Hero."}],["You pay the Hero's normal recruit cost, move it from the HQ into your discard pile, and refill that HQ space with a card from the Hero Deck. When all that is done, then you must use the \u201cWhen Recruited\u201c ability."],["When you play that card from your hand in later turns, don't use the \u201cWhen Recruited\u201c ability again. Instead, use the card's normal abilities, ",{"icon":2},", and ",{"icon":1},". A horizontal line separates the \u201cWhen Recruited\u201c ability from the card's normal abilities."],["If a special ability tells you to ",{"bold":"\u201cgain\u201c"}," a Hero or ",{"bold":"\u201cput\u201c"}," a Hero somewhere, then you ",{"bold":"don't"}," use that Hero's \u201cWhen Recruited\u201c ability, since you didn't pay ",{"icon":2}," and you didn't recruit that Hero. This is true even if the special ability tells you to \u201cgain\u201c the Hero from the HQ."],["However, you ",{"bold":"do"}," use the \u201cWhen Recruited\u201c ability if a special ability lets you \u201crecruit a Hero for free\u201c or recruit it at a reduced cost or from some unusual place, since then you are still recruiting the Hero."],["You may wish to keep some Heroes in the HQ until you especially need their \u201cWhen Recruited\u201c ability."]]}],"_id":"0WwJuoI46tnyoN98","detailsOutput":"The Inhumans' powerful decision to go to war is shown with new special abilities they use \u201cWhen Recruited.\u201c
  • Some Heroes say things like: \u201cWhen Recruited: You get +3<\/strong>.\u201c Use this \u201cWhen Recruited\u201c ability immediately when you recruit this Hero.<\/strong><\/li>
  • You pay the Hero's normal recruit cost, move it from the HQ into your discard pile, and refill that HQ space with a card from the Hero Deck. When all that is done, then you must use the \u201cWhen Recruited\u201c ability.<\/li>
  • When you play that card from your hand in later turns, don't use the \u201cWhen Recruited\u201c ability again. Instead, use the card's normal abilities, , and . A horizontal line separates the \u201cWhen Recruited\u201c ability from the card's normal abilities.<\/li>
  • If a special ability tells you to \u201cgain\u201c<\/strong> a Hero or \u201cput\u201c<\/strong> a Hero somewhere, then you don't<\/strong> use that Hero's \u201cWhen Recruited\u201c ability, since you didn't pay and you didn't recruit that Hero. This is true even if the special ability tells you to \u201cgain\u201c the Hero from the HQ.<\/li>
  • However, you do<\/strong> use the \u201cWhen Recruited\u201c ability if a special ability lets you \u201crecruit a Hero for free\u201c or recruit it at a reduced cost or from some unusual place, since then you are still recruiting the Hero.<\/li>
  • You may wish to keep some Heroes in the HQ until you especially need their \u201cWhen Recruited\u201c ability.<\/li><\/ul>"}

{"id":49,"value":"conqueror","label":"Conqueror","cardTypes":[1,2,3,4],"details":[["Some Villain cards have a special ability called \u201cConqueror,\u201d representing their desire to conquer and hold a specific part of the city."],{"points":[["Some Enemies say \u201cBridge Conqueror 3.\u201c This means ",{"bold":"\u201cThis gets +3"},{"icon":1},{"bold":" while any Villain is on the Bridge.\u201d"}],["The enemy gets the bonus wether itself or another Villain is on the Bridge."],["Different Villains and Masterminds have different Conqueror abilities, with different bonus numbers and referring to different city spaces."],["Some Hero cards also have abilities like \u201cRooftops Conqueror 2\u201d, meaning ",{"bold":"\u201cYou get +2"},{"icon":1},{"bold":" if any Villain is on the Rooftops.\u201d"}]]}],"_id":"1oJkDScIEitOMQnK","detailsOutput":"Some Villain cards have a special ability called \u201cConqueror,\u201d representing their desire to conquer and hold a specific part of the city.
  • Some Enemies say \u201cBridge Conqueror 3.\u201c This means \u201cThis gets +3<\/strong> while any Villain is on the Bridge.\u201d<\/strong><\/li>
  • The enemy gets the bonus wether itself or another Villain is on the Bridge.<\/li>
  • Different Villains and Masterminds have different Conqueror abilities, with different bonus numbers and referring to different city spaces.<\/li>
  • Some Hero cards also have abilities like \u201cRooftops Conqueror 2\u201d, meaning \u201cYou get +2<\/strong> if any Villain is on the Rooftops.\u201d<\/strong><\/li><\/ul>"}

{"id":17,"value":"crossdimensionalrampage","label":"Cross-Dimensional Rampage","cardTypes":[1,2,4,5],"details":[["As different Hulks rampage across planets and dimensions, only another Hulk can stop them!"],{"points":[["\u201cCross-Dimensional Hulk Rampage\u201d means ",{"bold":"\u201cEach player reveals one of their Hulk Heroes or a Hulk card in their Victory Pile or gains a Wound.\u201d"}],["You can reveal any card that includes the word \u201cHulk\u201d in its card name, Hero name, Villain Group name, or Tactics for Hulk Masterminds. This includes any Red Hulk, She-Hulk, Red She-Hulk, Skaar, Son of Hulk, Joe Fixit Grey Hulk, Hulkling, Hulk Gang, Cosmic Hulk Robot, Hulkbuster, Enchain the Hulk, and so on."],["You don\u2019t need to know the whole history of Marvel comics to judge who counts as a Hulk \u2013 just rely on whether the card says Hulk in its name or not. There are only a few, very specific exceptions we have to make to stay true to the characters: \u201cNul, Breaker of Worlds\u201d from Fear Itself and \u201cMaestro\u201d (core set) count as Hulks for this."],["Some Heroes can transform into Hulks, like Bruce Banner and Amadeus Cho. A puny \u201cBruce Banner\u201d card doesn\u2019t say \u201cHulk\u201d on it, so it can\u2019t stop a Hulk Rampage. But revealing the transformed Bruce Banner card named \u201cSavage Hulk Unleashed\u201d works."],["When a Cross-Dimensional Hulk Rampage happens, you can choose to gain the Wound, even if you have a Hulk that you already played or could otherwise reveal. You might want the Wound if you have cards that benefit from gaining Wounds, or a card that benefits from preventing Wounds."],["There are also Cross-Dimensional Void, Illuminati, Deadpool, Thor, Colossus, Zombie, Demon, Party, Ultron, and Wolverine (\u201cWeapon X\u201d and \u201cOld Man Logan\u201d included) Rampages."]]}],"_id":"1xTIW7E3qbCwEc7f","detailsOutput":"As different Hulks rampage across planets and dimensions, only another Hulk can stop them!<ul><li>\u201cCross-Dimensional Hulk Rampage\u201d means <strong>\u201cEach player reveals one of their Hulk Heroes or a Hulk card in their Victory Pile or gains a Wound.\u201d<\/strong><\/li><li>You can reveal any card that includes the word \u201cHulk\u201d in its card name, Hero name, Villain Group name, or Tactics for Hulk Masterminds. This includes any Red Hulk, She-Hulk, Red She-Hulk, Skaar, Son of Hulk, Joe Fixit Grey Hulk, Hulkling, Hulk Gang, Cosmic Hulk Robot, Hulkbuster, Enchain the Hulk, and so on.<\/li><li>You don\u2019t need to know the whole history of Marvel comics to judge who counts as a Hulk \u2013 just rely on whether the card says Hulk in its name or not. There are only a few, very specific exceptions we have to make to stay true to the characters: \u201cNul, Breaker of Worlds\u201d from Fear Itself and \u201cMaestro\u201d (core set) count as Hulks for this.<\/li><li>Some Heroes can transform into Hulks, like Bruce Banner and Amadeus Cho. A puny \u201cBruce Banner\u201d card doesn\u2019t say \u201cHulk\u201d on it, so it can\u2019t stop a Hulk Rampage. But revealing the transformed Bruce Banner card named \u201cSavage Hulk Unleashed\u201d works.<\/li><li>When a Cross-Dimensional Hulk Rampage happens, you can choose to gain the Wound, even if you have a Hulk that you already played or could otherwise reveal. You might want the Wound if you have cards that benefit from gaining Wounds, or a card that benefits from preventing Wounds.<\/li><li>There are also Cross-Dimensional Void, Illuminati, Deadpool, Thor, Colossus, Zombie, Demon, Party, Ultron, and Wolverine (\u201cWeapon X\u201d and \u201cOld Man Logan\u201d included) Rampages.<\/li><\/ul>"}

Some cards say things like \u201c3 Soulbind: You get + equal to that Villain\u2019s printed Victory Points.\u201d
  • This means \u201cIf you have played a <\/strong>3 Hero earlier this turn, you may choose a face up Villain card from your Victory Pile, turn it face down, and put it on the bottom of your Victory Pile. If you do, then do the listed Soulbind effect.\u201d<\/strong>At the end of the game when you are counting Victory Points, turn all those face down cards face up again and you can count their Victory Points. But until the end of the game, the face down cards count as not being in your Victory Pile at all.<\/li>
  • This is a great way to stop Rise of the 16Living Dead Villains from coming back to life out of your Victory Pile. The face down card can\u2019t be used for another Soulbind effect later. The face down card can\u2019t help you against 17. It doesn\u2019t count for effects that count the number of cards or Villains in your Victory Pile. Act as if the face down card is no longer in your Victory Pile at all, until you are counting Victory Points at the end of the game.<\/li>
  • Some cards ask you to Soulbind more specific things, like \u201cSoulbind a Henchman\u201d or \u201cSoulbind six Villains.\u201d<\/li>
  • Using Soulbind is usually optional.<\/strong> You generally don\u2019t have to use Soulbind if you don\u2019t want to, whether on a Hero card you played or a Villain you just fought. However, some cards explicitly say that you \u201cmust Soulbind,\u201d which means you have to do it.<\/li><\/ul>"}

From Weapon XII to Weapon XIII to Weapon XV, each of their sequence of killers is more deadly than the last.
  • On a Hero, \u201cWeapon X Sequence\u201d means \u201cyou get +<\/strong> equal to the longest sequence of different printed cost numbers on your cards.\u201d<\/strong><\/li>
  • \u201cYour cards\u201d includes both cards you\u2019ve played this turn and cards in your hand, so you can count both.<\/li>
  • For example, say your cards have the costs 0,4,2,7,3,3. Then each time you played a card with the Weapon X Sequence ability, you would get +3<\/strong> , since your longest sequence of different cost numbers is 2-3-4.<\/li>
  • Each number in the sequence must be one higher than the previous number. Your sequence can start with any number, including 0. You can\u2019t skip any number in the sequence. Having duplicates of the same cost doesn\u2019t help. If your costs are 0,0,0,4,4,6, then your longest sequence is 1 and you would get +1<\/strong>.<\/li>
  • After you play a Weapon X Sequence card, if you draw more cards later in the turn that would have extended your sequence, it\u2019s too late to go back and get more from the Weapon X Sequence you already played.<\/li>
  • \u201cDoubled Weapon X Sequence\u201d means double the bonus.<\/li>
  • Build your deck carefully to get long sequences!<\/li><\/ul>Enemies with Weapon X Sequence
    • On Enemies, Weapon X Sequence means \u201cThis Enemy gets +<\/strong> equal to the longest sequence of different printed cost numbers among cards in the HQ.\u201d<\/strong><\/li>
    • For example, say the Heroes in the HQ have printed costs 4,7,5,3,2. Then Weapon X Sequence gives an Enemy +4<\/strong> (for the sequence 2-3-4-5).<\/li>
    • It doesn\u2019t matter which HQ spaces those cards are in or if any of them are physically in any particular order.<\/li>
    • One clever move is to recruit a Hero from the HQ at the right time, disrupting an Enemy\u2019s Weapon X Sequence before you fight them. Take the above example where Heroes in the HQ have printed costs 4,7,5,3,2. If you recruit the 3-cost Hero and it gets replaced with a 5-cost Hero, you\u2019ve reduced the Enemy\u2019s Weapon X Sequence bonus from +4<\/strong> to +2<\/strong> .<\/li><\/ul>"}

{"id":70,"value":"thronesfavor","label":"Throne's Favor","cardTypes":[1,2,4,5],"details":[{"points":[["Some Heroes say \u201cYou gain the Throne's Favor.\u201c When this happens, take a nearby object to represent the Throne's Favor, like a coin, key, miniature, or pawn. You set aside the Throne's Favor object, and no one has the Throne's Favor until someone gains it again."],["You can only spend the Throne's Favor at the moment the card you're playing tells you to do so. You can't wait and spend it later in the turn. "],["The Throne's Favor is not a card. It never goes into decks or discard piles. Instead, when it comes up, just use whatever cool object is easily at hand. There's no need to store a special Throne's Favor object with the game."],["Cards can also cause the Mastermind to gain the Throne's Favor and\/or benefit from having it. If another player or Mastermind already has the Throne's Favor, and you gain it, then you take it from them.<\/li><li>If an ability tells you to gain the Throne's Favor, you must take it. You cannot leave it where it is.<\/li><li>Some Heroes say things like \u201cYou may spend the Throne's Favor to draw two cards.\u201c This means <strong>if you have the Throne's Favor, you may give it up to use the listed ability<\/strong>. Instead, when it comes up, just use whatever cool object is easily at hand. There's no need to store a special Throne's Favor object with the game.<\/li><li>Cards can also cause the Mastermind to gain the Throne's Favor and\/or benefit from having it.   • The Astral Plane is a single, unique space that only exists in games with cards that use the Astral Plane. It sits immediately to the right of the Villain Deck.<\/li>
  • While a Villain is in the Astral Plane, it has no physical form: It can only be fought with <\/strong>, not <\/strong>. To fight a 5<\/strong> Villain you must spend 5<\/strong>. When you fight a Villain in the Astral Plane, put it in your Victory Pile and do its Fight effect as normal.<\/li>
  • When a Villain enters the Astral Plane, any Villain already there escapes. <\/strong>This causes all the same effects as if that Villain had escaped the city (including KO\u2019ing from the HQ, discarding from captured Bystanders, and Escape abilities).<\/li>

  • The Mastermind \u201cNightmare\u201d can also enter the Astral Plane. While there, he can only be fought with , not . If he escapes the Astral Plane, do all the normal effects for a Villain escaping the city. Then do the Escape ability written on Nightmare, which moves him to the Mastermind space.<\/li>
  • The Astral Plane is not a city space. It\u2019s not \u201cadjacent\u201d to any city spaces. Card effects can\u2019t move or swap Villains to or from the Astral Plane unless they explicitly mention the Astral Plane.<\/li>
  • Villains do Ambush effects when they enter the city. The Astral Plane is not part of the city, so Villains that enter the Astral Plane don\u2019t do their Ambush effects at that time.<\/li>
  • For keywords from other sets: To fight a \u201cChivalrous Duel\u201d enemy in the Astral Plane, you must spend from a single Hero name. You must spend to use Excessive Violence or Human Shields from the Astral Plane. You can\u2019t use \u201cPiercing Energy\u201d on enemies in the Astral Plane. \u201cBribe\u201d and other cards that say \u201cYou can spend any combination of and to fight that Villain this turn.\u201d do not work against enemies in the Astral Plane.<\/li><\/ul>"}

{"id":13,"value":"artifact","label":"Artifact","cardTypes":[1,2,4],"details":[["Some Hero cards are also powerful \u201cArtifact\u201d cards. (They still count as Hero cards too.) This means you \u201ccontrol\u201d that Artifact. At end of turn, when you discard all the cards you played that turn, the Artifacts you control stay in front of you."],{"points":[["You can use Artifacts on the first turn you play them."],["You can control multiple Artifacts with the same card name and use each of them."],["You can only use Artifacts during your turn unless otherwise specified."],["If a card effect during any player\u2019s turn asks you to \u201cReveal a ",{"hc":3}," Hero,\u201d you may reveal a ",{"hc":3}," Hero Artifact you control. Card effects that say \u201cyour Heroes\u201d or \u201cHeroes you have\u201d include Hero Artifacts you control."],["However, you only \u201cplayed\u201d an Artifact on the turn you put it out, so it only activates Superpower Abilities (like \u201c",{"hc":4},": You get ",{"bold":"+1"},{"icon":1},".\u201d) on the turn you play the Artifact, not every turn of the game. Likewise, card effects that count \u201ceach Hero you played this turn\u201d only count an Artifact if you played it this turn."],["You don\u2019t have to use an Artifact\u2019s abilities on a turn if you don\u2019t want to."],["If you are using the Final Showdown, you can use Artifacts during your Showdown Turn."],["If a card effect like Rogue or Chameleon would let you \u201ccopy\u201d an Artifact card, then you can use that Artifact\u2019s \u201cOnce per turn\u201d ability once, and there is no other effect."]]}],"_id":"9SOjBFHCAHOLaZ1j","detailsOutput":"Some Hero cards are also powerful \u201cArtifact\u201d cards. (They still count as Hero cards too.) When you gain a Hero Artifact, put it in your discard pile like any other Hero card. When you draw that Artifact later in the game, you may play it in front of you and use its effects. This means you \u201ccontrol\u201d that Artifact. At end of turn, when you discard all the cards you played that turn, the Artifacts you control stay in front of you.
  • You can use Artifacts on the first turn you play them.<\/li>
  • You can control multiple Artifacts with the same card name and use each of them.<\/li>
  • You can only use Artifacts during your turn unless otherwise specified.<\/li>
  • If a card effect during any player\u2019s turn asks you to \u201cReveal a 3 Hero,\u201d you may reveal a 3 Hero Artifact you control. Card effects that say \u201cyour Heroes\u201d or \u201cHeroes you have\u201d include Hero Artifacts you control.<\/li>
  • However, you only \u201cplayed\u201d an Artifact on the turn you put it out, so it only activates Superpower Abilities (like \u201c4: You get +1<\/strong>.\u201d) on the turn you play the Artifact, not every turn of the game. Likewise, card effects that count \u201ceach Hero you played this turn\u201d only count an Artifact if you played it this turn.<\/li>
  • You don\u2019t have to use an Artifact\u2019s abilities on a turn if you don\u2019t want to.<\/li>
  • If you are using the Final Showdown, you can use Artifacts during your Showdown Turn.<\/li>
  • If a card effect like Rogue or Chameleon would let you \u201ccopy\u201d an Artifact card, then you can use that Artifact\u2019s \u201cOnce per turn\u201d ability once, and there is no other effect.<\/li><\/ul>"}

  • Some Heroes say things like \u201cExcessive Violence:<\/strong> Draw a card.\u201d<\/li>
  • Once per turn, you can spend 1<\/strong> more than you need to fight a Villain or Mastermind \u201cusing Excessive Violence.\u201d If you do, you get to use all the \u201cExcessive Violence\u201d abilities on cards you played this turn.<\/strong><\/li>
  • Say you\u2019ve played three Heroes with Excessive Violence abilities this turn. If you spend 8<\/strong> to fight a Villain or Mastermind that has 7<\/strong>, then you\u2019ll get to use all three Excessive Violence abilities!<\/li>
  • If you don\u2019t fight anything this turn, or if you don\u2019t spend an extra 1<\/strong> on someone, then you won\u2019t be able to use Excessive Violence.<\/li>
  • Since you can only fight \u201cusing Excessive Violence\u201d once per turn, you can only use a card\u2019s Excessive Violence ability once per turn. (It\u2019s OK to play two cards with the same card name, fight an enemy \u201cusing Excessive Violence\u201d and use both of those cards\u2019 Excessive Violence abilities.)<\/li>
  • Do the enemy\u2019s Fight effect and the Excessive Violence abilities in any order of your choice.<\/li>
  • If you fight using Excessive Violence and then draw or play more cards with Excessive Violence abilities later in the turn, it will be too late to use those abilities.<\/li>
  • Gravity Mines says \u201cTriggered Artifact \u2014 Whenever you use Excessive Violence, draw a card.\u201d You can use this even if this Artifact is the only Excessive Violence card you have, or combine it with other Excessive Violence cards.<\/li><\/ul>"}

It\u2019s also used by characters that can change the size of a weapon, technology, or energy.
  • Some Hero cards say things like \u201cSize-Changing: <\/strong>1.\u201c This means \u201cYou can recruit this card for 2<\/strong> less if you played any <\/strong>1 cards this turn.\u201d<\/strong><\/li>
  • Likewise, some Villain cards say things like \u201cSize-Changing: <\/strong>5.\u201c This means \u201cYou can fight this Villain for 2<\/strong> less if you played any <\/strong>5 cards this turn.\u201d<\/strong><\/li>
  • Some Divided Cards say \u201cSize-Changing: 5\u201d on one side and \u201cSize-Changing: 4\u201d on the other side. You can recruit either side of the card with its own Size-Changing discount, but you can\u2019t get both discounts at once.<\/li>
  • Some Heroes and Villains say things like \u201cSize-Changing: <\/strong>4, 1.\u201c If you played any 4 Heroes this turn, the cost is 2 less. If you played any 1 Heroes, the cost is 2 less. If you played both a 4 Hero and a 1 Hero this turn, then the cost is 4 less.<\/li>
  • Fin Fang Foom and one of his Monsters Unleashed even say \u201cSize-Changing: <\/strong>4, 2, 1, 5, 3.\u201c You can pay 2<\/strong> less to fight them for each of these Hero Classes you played this turn.<\/li>
  • Note:<\/strong> For a typical Size-Changing card, it doesn\u2019t matter how many Heroes of that Hero Class you played \u2013 it only matters if you played any Heroes of that Hero Class or not.<\/li>
  • After you\u2019ve recruited a card, Size-Changing doesn\u2019t do anything else on that card.<\/li>
  • The Size-Changing card's cost is only changed during the moment you are recruiting it, not other times.<\/li>
  • If a Hero in the HQ already has \u201cSize-Changing: <\/strong>5\u201d and it gains \u201cSize-Changing: <\/strong>5, 3\u201d from another special ability like the Sporr Villain, it just ends up with \u201cSize-Changing: <\/strong>5, 3.\u201d A card can\u2019t have a typical Size-Changing for the same Hero Class twice.<\/li><\/ul>"}

This ability works like regular Size-Changing, but with a couple of twists.
  • Some cards say \u201cMicroscopic Size-Changing 555.\u201d<\/li>
  • This means \u201cYou can recruit this card for 2<\/strong> less for each <\/strong>5 card you played this turn, counting up to three <\/strong>5 cards.\u201d<\/strong><\/li>
  • If you played 1 5 Hero this turn, this card costs you 2 less. If you played 2 5 Heroes, it costs you 4 less. If you played 3+ 5 Heroes, it costs you 6 less.<\/li>
  • Playing a fourth 5 card wouldn\u2019t reduce this cost any further since there are only three 5 icons listed in this particular Microscopic Size-Changing ability.<\/li>
  • The second twist is that Microscopic Size-Changing can actually reduce a card\u2019s Recruit cost to zero or even a negative number!<\/strong> When you recruit a Microscopic Size-Changing Hero with a negative cost, you actually gain that many Recruit points!<\/strong><\/li>
  • Some Villains also have Microscopic Size-Changing. It works the same way, letting you fight that Villain for 2<\/strong> less for each card of the correct Hero Class you played this turn, up to the number of icons shown in the Microscopic Size-Changing ability.<\/li>
  • Likewise, if you fight a Villain with Microscopic Size-Changing and reduce its value to a negative number, you actually gain that many points when you fight it! You don\u2019t even need to have any points before you fight them.<\/li>
  • For example, say you play five 1 Heroes, then fight a Villain with 3<\/strong> and \u201cMicroscopic Size-Changing <\/strong>1111.\u201d<\/strong> The Villain\u2019s decreases to -5, and you actually gain +5<\/strong> when you fight them! (The 5th 1 Hero you played didn\u2019t reduce the , since the Microscopic Size-Changing ability only had 4 icons.)<\/li>
  • Building the right deck and shrinking down to the crazy backwards physics of the Microverse can create some very powerful turns!<\/li>
  • Microscopic Size-Changing is a type of 26, so any effect that mentions 26 works with Microscopic Size-Changing.<\/li><\/ul>"}

However, card effects that say \u201crecruit a Hero from the HQ for free\u201d don't work on Haunted Heroes, since you can't recruit them."],["If something causes a Haunted Hero to leave the HQ, then the Haunting Villain stays in that HQ space and Haunts the new Hero that arrives to refill that HQ space."],["If an HQ space is \u201cdestroyed,\u201d KO any Haunted Hero there and the Haunting Villain there enters the city, ignoring any Ambush effects."]]}],"_id":"FIQw5emezJXkRg8c","detailsOutput":"Zarathos and his Fallen can control Heroes' bodies like twisted puppets. They say things like \u201cAmbush: Haunt the rightmost unhaunted Hero in the HQ.
  • This means: Tuck this Villain beneath that Hero, 'Haunting' it, so you can see the Villain's name. Players can't recruit that Haunted Hero while the Haunting Villain is under it.<\/strong><\/li>
  • Instead, a player can spend equal to the Haunted Hero's cost to \u201cexorcise\u201d that Haunted Hero. If a player does, they either KO the Haunted Hero or choose a player to gain it. Then the Haunting Villain enters the city, ignoring any Ambush effects it has.<\/li>
  • While a Villain is Haunting a Hero, you can't fight the Haunting Villain itself - you have to spend to exorcise the Haunted Hero first, driving the Haunting Villain into the city so you can finish it off there.<\/li>
  • Exorcizing a Haunted Hero is not a \u201cfight\u201d - don't do any Fight abilities on the Haunting Villain. <\/li>
  • A Hero can't be Haunted by two Villains at once. Haunt abilities all say to Haunt an \u201cunhaunted Hero.\u201d<\/li>
  • Zarathos\u2019 Master Strikes and Tactics can cause him to Haunt a Hero in the same way. Exorcizing that Hero drives Zarathos back to the Mastermind space.<\/li>
  • A \u201cHaunted Hero\u201d is still a Hero, so it can still be affected by things that affect Heroes in the HQ. A Villain escaping the city that KOs a Hero from the HQ (that costs 6 or less) can KO a Haunted Hero. Card effects that let you \u201cgain a Hero from the HQ\u201d or \u201cPut a Hero from the HQ on the bottom of the Hero Deck\u201d still work on Haunted Heroes. However, card effects that say \u201crecruit a Hero from the HQ for free\u201d don't work on Haunted Heroes, since you can't recruit them.<\/li>
  • If something causes a Haunted Hero to leave the HQ, then the Haunting Villain stays in that HQ space and Haunts the new Hero that arrives to refill that HQ space.<\/li>
  • If an HQ space is \u201cdestroyed,\u201d KO any Haunted Hero there and the Haunting Villain there enters the city, ignoring any Ambush effects.<\/li><\/ul>"}

  • Villainous Weapons are not Villains.<\/li>

  • An enemy can use any number of Weapons at the same time, getting all of their bonuses combined.<\/li>
  • When a Villain with any number of Villainous Weapons escapes the city, the Mastermind captures all those Weapons<\/strong>, getting their bonuses.<\/li>
  • When you fight a Villain or Mastermind holding any number of Weapons, put all those Weapons into your discard pile as Artifacts.<\/strong><\/li>
  • When you have a Villainous Weapon in your hand, you can play it just like any other 13.<\/li>
  • You never get the Weapon\u2019s printed <\/strong> bonus<\/strong> when you play the Artifact or control it. Only Villains and Masterminds get that bonus. You only get the specific Artifact abilities written on the card.<\/li>
  • Villainous Weapons you have captured as Artifacts have 0 cost<\/strong>, have no color or Hero Class, and don\u2019t count as Hero cards or Villain cards. Since they have no cost, Villainous Weapons can never make you Worthy. (How appropriate\u2026)<\/li>
  • If you have gained a Villainous Weapon, and a card effect makes an enemy capture that Weapon again, then it works as a Villainous Weapon again until someone defeats that enemy to reclaim it.<\/li>
  • Malekith, Hela, and Ronan have Mastermind Tactics that turn into Villainous Weapons. You win when the Mastermind has no face down Tactics left under them, even if there are still some Tactics that have turned into other card types.<\/li><\/ul>"}

This is represented by this matched pair of keywords.
  • Some Hero cards say things like \u201cMoonlight: Draw a card.\u201d Others say things like \u201cSunlight: You get +2<\/strong>.\u201d<\/li>
  • Moonlight abilities work only when most of the Heroes in the HQ have odd-numbered costs. Likewise, Sunlight abilities work only when most of the Heroes in the HQ have even-numbered costs.<\/strong><\/li>
  • Besides Heroes, some Villains and Masterminds also say they get extra or abilities during Moonlight or Sunlight.<\/li>
  • If there are a tied number of odd and even-numbered Heroes in the HQ (perhaps because some HQ spaces were added or destroyed), then neither Moonlight nor Sunlight is in effect.<\/li>
  • Only the printed costs matter. Abilities that change the costs of Heroes in the HQ won't affect Moonlight and Sunlight.<\/li>
  • \u201cHaunted Heroes\u201d are still Heroes, so they still count towards Moonlight and Sunlight. (Any Villains Haunting them don't count, since they aren't Heroes.)<\/li>
  • \u201cDivided Cards\u201d from Civil War and other sets count as just one card for Moonlight\/Sunlight.<\/li><\/ul>Manipulating Moonlight and Sunlight:<\/strong>
    • Clever players can recruit cards out of the HQ at crucial times to manipulate whether it is Moonlight or Sunlight.<\/li>
    • When Villains scape, KO\u2019ing Heroes from the HQ, you can also use this to shift towards Moonlight or Sunlight.<\/li>
    • In a game with many Moonlight and Sunlight effects, some players like to shift the odd-numbered cost cards in the HQ down a little bit. This makes it easier to tell at a glance whether Moonlight or Sunlight is in effect.<\/li><\/ul>Moonlight and Sunlight Timing<\/strong>As always, do a card\u2019s abilities in the order they are listed. You check Moonlight or Sunlight at the moment when you would use that ability.
      • For example, Sunspot has a card that says \u201cMoonlight<\/strong>: You may put a Hero from the HQ on the bottom of the Hero Deck. Sunlight<\/strong>: Draw a card.\u201d Sunspot\u2019s cards primarily benefit from Sunlight, so the Moonlight ability here mostly helps him push the HQ towards Sunlight.<\/li>
      • You do these abilities in the order they are listed. So if there are three odd-numbered cards in the HQ, and you play this card, you might be able to use the Moonlight ability to change the HQ to have only two odd-numbered cards, and then you could immediately use the Sunlight ability.<\/li>
      • Once you are completely done playing a Hero card or fighting a Villain with a Moonlight or Sunlight ability, move on. If later in the turn you change Moonlight or Sunlight, you don\u2019t go back in time to change the past.<\/li><\/ul>Remembering Odd and Even<\/strong>
        • To help you remember that Moonlight uses odd-numbered cards, all the Moonlight-loving Hero cards have odd-numbered costs. Likewise, all the Sunlight-loving Hero cards have even-numbered costs.<\/li>
        • Similarly, Moonlight-loving Villains all have odd-numbered while Sunlight-loving Villains all have even-numbered Of course, some cards use both Sunlight and Moonlight, so they don\u2019t follow this guideline.<\/li>
        • You can also remember with the phrase \u201cThe odd ones come out at night...\u201d<\/li><\/ul>"}

While pushing forward, they feed on the resources of new territory, becoming more powerful. This is represented by the new \u201cMomentum\u201c keyword.
  • Some Villains say things like \u201cMomentum 3.\u201c This means \u201cThis Villain gets +3<\/strong> if it entered another city space this turn.\u201c<\/strong><\/li>
  • This works on the turn the Villain enters the city. It also works on any other turn when it is pushed into another city space by another Villain, or by a special ability moving or swapping it to another space.<\/li>
  • The Mastermind Annihilus has the variant \u201cMass Momentum 2<\/strong>.\u201c This means he gets +2<\/strong> for each Villain currently in the city that entered a new city space this turn.<\/strong> (This doesn't include Villains who entered the Escape Pile this turn.)<\/li>
  • For both Momentum and Mass Momentum, it doesn't matter how many different city spaces a Villain entered during a turn. It only matters if it entered any new city spaces at all.<\/li>
  • If a board gets complicated, with special abilities moving Villains around, some players like to shift Momentum Villains up a bit to help signal that they have entered a new space this turn.<\/li><\/ul>"}

  • Some Hero cards say things like \u201cHyperspeed 5.\u201d This means \u201cReveal the top 5 cards of your deck. You get +1<\/strong> for each card with an <\/strong> icon you revealed this way. Discard all those cards.<\/strong>\u201d<\/li>

Sometimes they instantly switch to new fighting stances, while other times they switch in new Heroes altogether.
  • Some Hero cards say things like \u201cSwitcheroo 4.<\/strong>\u201d<\/li>
  • This means \u201cYou can reveal this card from your hand and put it on the bottom of the Hero Deck. If you do, you may put a Hero of the specified printed cost from the HQ into your hand.<\/strong>\u201d<\/li>
  • So when you have a Switcheroo card in your hand, you can choose to play it for its normal , , and other effects. Or you can choose to permanently swap it for another card in the HQ instead.<\/li>
  • You use Switcheroo instead of playing the card. So when you Switcheroo, you don\u2019t get any , , or other effects from the Switcheroo card that you put on the bottom of the Hero Deck.<\/li>
  • Remember:<\/strong> You put the Switcheroo card on the bottom of the collective Hero Deck on the board \u2013 not your personal deck.<\/li>
  • It\u2019s totally fine to Switcheroo into a card of a different Hero Name.<\/li>
  • You can only use Switcheroo during your turn, when you could play cards from your hand. So you can\u2019t use it during other players\u2019 turns, and you can\u2019t use it while playing a card from the Villain Deck, like during a Master Strike, Scheme Twist, or Villain\u2019s Ambush ability.<\/li>
  • You can\u2019t Switcheroo into S.H.I.E.L.D. Officers or Sidekicks, since they aren\u2019t in the HQ.<\/li>
  • Switcheroo doesn\u2019t count as \u201crecruiting\u201d a Hero, so you can\u2019t use abilities like Wall-Crawl or Soaring Flight when you Switcheroo.<\/li>
  • Switcheroo uses the \u201cprinted cost\u201d of cards in the HQ, so even if special abilities make cards in the HQ cost more or less, Switcheroo still uses the cost number literally printed on the card.<\/li><\/ul>"}

{"id":91,"value":"whatif","label":"What If...?","cardTypes":[1],"details":[["This new keyword highlights how a Hero\u2019s destiny can pivot on a single crucial choice, with consequences that spill through the rest of that dimension. Some Hero cards say things like \u201c",{"bold":"What If\u2026?"},": You get ",{"bold":"+3"},{"icon":2},".\u201d"],{"points":[["This means ",{"bold":"\u201cChoose a Hero Class or Hero Name. Then reveal the top card of your deck, and either put it back on top of your deck or discard it. If the revealed card had the Hero Class or Hero Name you chose, then do the What If effect.\u201d"}],["What If...? is not allowed to trigger on 0-cost grey starting cards like S.H.I.E.L.D. Agent or S.H.I.E.L.D. Trooper, so don\u2019t choose those Hero Names."],["Even if a What If...? ability misses, it\u2019s still valuable to be able to choose to put your top card in your discard pile or not. For example, it can give you key information about your top card so you know what to choose with your next What If...? card that turn. Or if the top card is a S.H.I.E.L.D. Agent, you can discard it so you have a chance to hit with your next What If...? ability that turn and so you don\u2019t have to draw it next turn."],["If you choose a Hero Name like \u201cBlack Widow,\u201d that will trigger on any card whose Hero Name is literally \u201cBlack Widow\u201d as well as any Hero Name that contains \u201cBlack Widow\u201d, such as \u201cApocalyptic Black Widow.\u201d However, you have to choose an actual Hero Name. You can\u2019t choose just the word \u201cCaptain\u201d and trigger on both Captain America and Captain Carter cards, since the single word \u201cCaptain\u201d isn\u2019t a Hero Name."]]},[{"bold":"Increasing Your Chances with What If...?"}],["There are lots of ways you can increase the chance that your What If...? abilities will work:"],{"points":[["First: There are several cards in this set that let you reveal the top card of your deck or put a card on top of your deck, so that you know what to choose with What If...?."],["Second: You can try focusing your deck on a single Hero Class or single Hero Name."],["Third: Collecting lots of What If...? cards can let you see the top card with the first What If...?, so you know what to guess with the rest of your What If...? abilities that turn."],["Fourth: You can look for ways to KO your 0-cost starter cards and avoid or KO Wounds."]]}],"_id":"YPho6aJWyiyZYlRx","detailsOutput":"This new keyword highlights how a Hero\u2019s destiny can pivot on a single crucial choice, with consequences that spill through the rest of that dimension. Some Hero cards say things like \u201cWhat If\u2026?<\/strong>: You get +3<\/strong>.\u201d
  • This means \u201cChoose a Hero Class or Hero Name. Then reveal the top card of your deck, and either put it back on top of your deck or discard it. If the revealed card had the Hero Class or Hero Name you chose, then do the What If effect.\u201d<\/strong><\/li>
  • What If...? is not allowed to trigger on 0-cost grey starting cards like S.H.I.E.L.D. Agent or S.H.I.E.L.D. Trooper, so don\u2019t choose those Hero Names.<\/li>
  • Even if a What If...? ability misses, it\u2019s still valuable to be able to choose to put your top card in your discard pile or not. For example, it can give you key information about your top card so you know what to choose with your next What If...? card that turn. Or if the top card is a S.H.I.E.L.D. Agent, you can discard it so you have a chance to hit with your next What If...? ability that turn and so you don\u2019t have to draw it next turn.<\/li>
  • If you choose a Hero Name like \u201cBlack Widow,\u201d that will trigger on any card whose Hero Name is literally \u201cBlack Widow\u201d as well as any Hero Name that contains \u201cBlack Widow\u201d, such as \u201cApocalyptic Black Widow.\u201d However, you have to choose an actual Hero Name. You can\u2019t choose just the word \u201cCaptain\u201d and trigger on both Captain America and Captain Carter cards, since the single word \u201cCaptain\u201d isn\u2019t a Hero Name.<\/li><\/ul>Increasing Your Chances with What If...?<\/strong>There are lots of ways you can increase the chance that your What If...? abilities will work:
    • First: There are several cards in this set that let you reveal the top card of your deck or put a card on top of your deck, so that you know what to choose with What If...?.<\/li>
    • Second: You can try focusing your deck on a single Hero Class or single Hero Name.<\/li>
    • Third: Collecting lots of What If...? cards can let you see the top card with the first What If...?, so you know what to guess with the rest of your What If...? abilities that turn.<\/li>
    • Fourth: You can look for ways to KO your 0-cost starter cards and avoid or KO Wounds.<\/li><\/ul>"}

{"id":33,"value":"hiddenwitness","label":"Hidden Witness","cardTypes":[2,4,5],"details":[["In a world of Noir, conspiracies are hard to unravel, betrayal is commonplace, and it\u2019s hard to determine who the real Villains are."],{"points":[["This keyword represents Villains and Masterminds hiding behind layers of informants, victims, and stooges. To find these Villains, you must track down and interview Hidden Witnesses who know their locations."],["Some Villains say things like \u201c",{"bold":"Ambush"},": This Villain captures 2 ",{"bold":"Hidden Witnesses"},".\u201d This means the Villain captures the top 2 cards of the Bystander Stack, ",{"bold":"face-down"},", as Hidden Witnesses. You can\u2019t fight a Villain while it has a Hidden Witness."],["During your turn ",{"bold":"you can pay 2"},{"icon":2}," to rescue a Hidden Witness any number of times and put it in your Victory Pile."],["Hidden Witnesses still count as Bystanders. When you rescue one, you get any special \u201cWhen you rescue this Bystander \u2026\u201d effect written on it. It stays in your Victory Pile as a normal, face-up Bystander."],["A Villain can have face-up Bystanders and face-down Hidden Witnesses at the same time. You\u2019ll need to pay to rescue the face-down Hidden Witnesses. Then, you can fight the Villain, which will automatically rescue the face-up Bystanders."],["If a Villain escapes with any number of Bystanders, including Hidden Witnesses, it will cause all players to discard a single card, just like a Villain escaping with any normal Bystanders. Hidden Witnesses carried away by escaping Villains stay in the Escape Pile as normal, face-up Bystanders."],["You can pay to rescue Hidden Witnesses even if you\u2019re not going to fight that Villain during that turn. You can also rescue just some of the Hidden Witnesses and leave others for later."],["If a special ability lets you \u201cDefeat a Villain for free,\u201d you automatically rescue all the Hidden Witnesses on it without paying ",{"icon":2},"."],["Masterminds and Schemes can have Hidden Witnesses on them too. They work the same way."]]},[{"bold":"Charles Xavier, Professor of Crime"}],["This Mastermind can put Hidden Witnesses on Heroes in the HQ. These work the same way as other Hidden Witnesses."],{"points":[["You can\u2019t recruit Heroes that have Hidden Witnesses on them until someone pays to rescue those Hidden Witnesses."],["Those Hidden Witnesses still count as Bystanders to increase Charles Xavier\u2019s ",{"icon":1},"."],["If a Hero in the HQ is KO\u2019d by an escaping Villain or leaves the HQ because of some special ability, then KO any Hidden Witnesses on that Hero."]]}],"_id":"YxItrRXbYRGOjjmr","detailsOutput":"In a world of Noir, conspiracies are hard to unravel, betrayal is commonplace, and it\u2019s hard to determine who the real Villains are.
  • This keyword represents Villains and Masterminds hiding behind layers of informants, victims, and stooges. To find these Villains, you must track down and interview Hidden Witnesses who know their locations.<\/li>
  • Some Villains say things like \u201cAmbush<\/strong>: This Villain captures 2 Hidden Witnesses<\/strong>.\u201d This means the Villain captures the top 2 cards of the Bystander Stack, face-down<\/strong>, as Hidden Witnesses. You can\u2019t fight a Villain while it has a Hidden Witness.<\/li>
  • During your turn you can pay 2<\/strong> to rescue a Hidden Witness any number of times and put it in your Victory Pile.<\/li>
  • Hidden Witnesses still count as Bystanders. When you rescue one, you get any special \u201cWhen you rescue this Bystander \u2026\u201d effect written on it. It stays in your Victory Pile as a normal, face-up Bystander.<\/li>
  • A Villain can have face-up Bystanders and face-down Hidden Witnesses at the same time. You\u2019ll need to pay to rescue the face-down Hidden Witnesses. Then, you can fight the Villain, which will automatically rescue the face-up Bystanders.<\/li>
  • If a Villain escapes with any number of Bystanders, including Hidden Witnesses, it will cause all players to discard a single card, just like a Villain escaping with any normal Bystanders. Hidden Witnesses carried away by escaping Villains stay in the Escape Pile as normal, face-up Bystanders.<\/li>
  • You can pay to rescue Hidden Witnesses even if you\u2019re not going to fight that Villain during that turn. You can also rescue just some of the Hidden Witnesses and leave others for later.<\/li>
  • If a special ability lets you \u201cDefeat a Villain for free,\u201d you automatically rescue all the Hidden Witnesses on it without paying .<\/li>
  • Masterminds and Schemes can have Hidden Witnesses on them too. They work the same way.<\/li><\/ul>Charles Xavier, Professor of Crime<\/strong>This Mastermind can put Hidden Witnesses on Heroes in the HQ. These work the same way as other Hidden Witnesses.
    • You can\u2019t recruit Heroes that have Hidden Witnesses on them until someone pays to rescue those Hidden Witnesses.<\/li>
    • Those Hidden Witnesses still count as Bystanders to increase Charles Xavier\u2019s .<\/li>
    • If a Hero in the HQ is KO\u2019d by an escaping Villain or leaves the HQ because of some special ability, then KO any Hidden Witnesses on that Hero.<\/li><\/ul>"}

Their \u201cExcessive Kindness\u201d abilities work just like 30, except that you trigger them by spending 1<\/strong> more than you need when recruiting a Hero.
  • Some Heroes say things like \u201cExcessive Kindness:<\/strong> Draw a card.\u201d<\/li>
  • Once per turn, you can spend 1<\/strong> more than you need to recruit a Hero \u201cusing Excessive Kindness.\u201d If you do, you get to use all the \u201cExcessive Kindness abilities on cards you played this turn.<\/strong><\/li>
  • Say you\u2019ve played three Heroes with Excessive Kindness abilities this turn. If you spend 8<\/strong> to recruit a Hero that has cost 7, then you\u2019ll get to use all three Excessive Kindness abilities!<\/li>
  • If you don\u2019t recruit anything this turn, or if you don\u2019t spend an extra 1<\/strong> on someone, then you won\u2019t be able to use Excessive Kindness.<\/li>
  • Since you can only recruit \u201cusing Excessive Kindness once per turn, you can only use a card\u2019s Excessive Kindness ability once per turn. (It\u2019s OK to play two cards with the same card name, recruit a Hero \u201cusing Excessive Kindness and use both of those cards\u2019 Excessive Kindness abilities.)<\/li>
  • If you recruit using Excessive Kindness and then draw or play more cards with Excessive Kindness abilities later in the turn, it will be too late to use those abilities.<\/li><\/ul>"}

{"id":87,"value":"endgame","label":"Endgame","cardTypes":[1,2,4],"details":[["This keyword represents how the Children of Thanos attack most fiercely in their final battles of their Endgame: the destruction of the Avengers, Wakanda, half of all life, and eventually all life in the universe. Some enemies say things like \u201dEndgame: ",{"bold":"+3"},{"icon":1},"\u201d."],{"points":[[{"bold":"It is the \u201dEndgame\u201d whenever the Villain Deck holds 8 cards per player or fewer."}],["This gives Enemies their Endgame ",{"icon":1}," bonus or other listed Endgame abilities."],["Captain Marvel is not in ",{"italic":"Infinity War"}," and arrives only in the ",{"italic":"Endgame"}," movie, reaching her full power in the final battle. Accordingly, she uses the Endgame keyword in the same way Enemies do."],["If you reach the Endgame and then cards are added back to the Villain Deck somehow, it might not be the Endgame anymore. If a Scheme has multiple Villain Decks, it is the Endgame if any of them are small enough."],["Some Enemies have special abilities that say \u201dIt is the Endgame this turn.\u201d This temporarily activates Endgame abilities for all Heroes and Enemies across the game this turn."],["Captain Marvel also has a card which says \u201dFor the rest of this turn, it is the Endgame for your Hero cards.\u201d This turns on Heroes' Endgame abilities, but it does not activete Enemies' Endgame abilities."],["If you are playing with Endgame abilities, you may find it easier to count 8 cards per player from the bottom of the Villain Deck and put that bottom section to the side of the rest of the Villain Deck. Or keep the Villain Deck in one stack but turn that bottom section of the deck 90 degrees, perpendicular to the top section. This will make it easier to see how close you are to the Endgame. Remember that it's technically all still one deck, so you might not want to do this if using a Scheme that shuffles the Villain Deck, like \u201dSacrifice for the Soul Stone.\u201d"]]}],"_id":"bRuwzsQwche6emOZ","detailsOutput":"This keyword represents how the Children of Thanos attack most fiercely in their final battles of their Endgame: the destruction of the Avengers, Wakanda, half of all life, and eventually all life in the universe. Some enemies say things like \u201dEndgame: +3<\/strong>\u201d.
  • It is the \u201dEndgame\u201d whenever the Villain Deck holds 8 cards per player or fewer.<\/strong><\/li>
  • This gives Enemies their Endgame bonus or other listed Endgame abilities.<\/li>
  • Captain Marvel is not in Infinity War and arrives only in the Endgame movie, reaching her full power in the final battle. Accordingly, she uses the Endgame keyword in the same way Enemies do.<\/li>
  • If you reach the Endgame and then cards are added back to the Villain Deck somehow, it might not be the Endgame anymore. If a Scheme has multiple Villain Decks, it is the Endgame if any of them are small enough.<\/li>
  • Some Enemies have special abilities that say \u201dIt is the Endgame this turn.\u201d This temporarily activates Endgame abilities for all Heroes and Enemies across the game this turn.<\/li>
  • Captain Marvel also has a card which says \u201dFor the rest of this turn, it is the Endgame for your Hero cards.\u201d This turns on Heroes' Endgame abilities, but it does not activete Enemies' Endgame abilities.<\/li>
  • If you are playing with Endgame abilities, you may find it easier to count 8 cards per player from the bottom of the Villain Deck and put that bottom section to the side of the rest of the Villain Deck. Or keep the Villain Deck in one stack but turn that bottom section of the deck 90 degrees, perpendicular to the top section. This will make it easier to see how close you are to the Endgame. Remember that it's technically all still one deck, so you might not want to do this if using a Scheme that shuffles the Villain Deck, like \u201dSacrifice for the Soul Stone.\u201d<\/li><\/ul>"}

The copy doesn\u2019t stay in play as an Artifact."]]}],"_id":"cXs0frKJdg9PhVBX","detailsOutput":"Marvel\u2019s sorcerers invoke Rituals of awesome power, anchored by mystic talismans. This is represented with a special type of 13: Ritual Artifacts. These use the 13 rules, with some new twists.
  • They say things like \u201cRitual Artifact \u2014 If you drew a card, you may discard this Artifact to get +3<\/strong>.\u201c<\/li>
  • If you have fulfilled the listed Ritual condition this turn, you can discard the Ritual Artifact to get the listed effect.<\/li>
  • You don\u2019t have to use the Ritual Artifact even if you fulfill the Ritual condition. You might want to save it for a future turn instead of discarding it.<\/li>
  • You can use as many Ritual Artifacts as you wish in a turn, including using multiple Ritual Artifacts with the same name. If you draw one card, that\u2019s enough to use the Rituals of multiple Artifacts that each have the condition \u201cDraw a card.\u201d<\/li>
  • If you use a \u201cdraw a card\u201d ability, and it draws you a Ritual Artifact with the condition \u201cdraw a card,\u201d then you can play that Artifact and use it right away. It\u2019s ok that the Artifact wasn\u2019t in play when you fulfilled the Ritual condition earlier in the turn.<\/li>
  • If a card lets you \u201ccopy\u201d a Ritual Artifact card or \u201cplay a copy of it,\u201d then you can use its Ritual effect (or \u201cThrown Artifact\u201d or \u201cOnce per turn\u201d Artifact ability) once, and you don\u2019t need to fulfill the ritual condition. You don\u2019t need to immediately discard the copy card to use the Ritual. The copy doesn\u2019t stay in play as an Artifact.<\/li><\/ul>"}

Everyone else \u201closes.\u201d"],["For example, in a 3-player game, say Alana\u2019s score is 6, Piper\u2019s score is 6, Melody\u2019s score is 4, and Evil\u2019s score is 6. Then Alana, Piper, and the Mastermind all win the contest, and Melody loses the contest."],["The card lists outcomes for winning & losing."],["A few cards reveal a Hero card and use its colors for a contest. This can create contests that are multicolor, such as \u201cContest of Champions ",{"hc":5},", ",{"hc":3},".\u201d In this case, any card that includes either ",{"hc":5}," or ",{"hc":3}," will match the contest and have its score doubled. (A card that\u2019s both ",{"hc":5}," and ",{"hc":3}," won\u2019t be quadrupled.)"],["Some contests say that Evil reveals 4 or 6 cards from the Hero Deck. Evil\u2019s Contest Score is still the highest-scoring single card."]]}],"_id":"hZl3enb5g6F0mejv","detailsOutput":"The Grandmaster and the Elders of the Universe are literally immortal. To them, mortals are merely playthings. This is shown with the Contest of Champions keyword. Some Villains and Masterminds say things like \u201cAmbush: Contest of Champions 4.\u201d When this happens:<ul><li>Each player in turn reveals a single card, either from their hand, or that they played this turn, or the top card of their deck. That player announces their \u201cContest Score,\u201d which is that card\u2019s printed cost, doubled if it\u2019s a 4 card.<\/li><li>You must choose carefully whether to use the best score you have from your hand, or to take a risk by trying the top card of your deck instead.<\/li><li>After all players have announced their Contest Score, then Evil tries to win the contest. Reveal the top two cards of the Hero Deck, and Evil uses whichever card gives the highest Contest Score (taking account of any doubling). Again, this is the card\u2019s printed cost, doubled if it\u2019s a 4 card. Then put both those cards on the bottom of the Hero Deck.<\/li><li>Whichever score is highest (or tied for highest) \u201cwins\u201d the contest. Everyone else \u201closes.\u201d<\/li><li>For example, in a 3-player game, say Alana\u2019s score is 6, Piper\u2019s score is 6, Melody\u2019s score is 4, and Evil\u2019s score is 6. Then Alana, Piper, and the Mastermind all win the contest, and Melody loses the contest.<\/li><li>The card lists outcomes for winning & losing.<\/li><li>A few cards reveal a Hero card and use its colors for a contest. This can create contests that are multicolor, such as \u201cContest of Champions 5, 3.\u201d In this case, any card that includes either 5 or 3 will match the contest and have its score doubled. (A card that\u2019s both 5 and 3 won\u2019t be quadrupled.)<\/li><li>Some contests say that Evil reveals 4 or 6 cards from the Hero Deck. Evil\u2019s Contest Score is still the highest-scoring single card.<\/li><\/ul>"}

{"id":14,"value":"thrownartifact","label":"Thrown Artifact","cardTypes":[1,2,4],"details":[["These are ",{"keyword":13}," cards that a player can \u201cthrow\u201d at the perfect moment. When you gain a card that\u2019s an Artifact, put it into your discard pile like any other. When you draw that Artifact later in the game, you may play it in front of you when the time comes. This means you \u201ccontrol\u201d that Artifact. At the end of your turn, when you discard all the cards you played that turn, the Artifacts you control stay in front of you for future turns and are not discarded."],{"points":[[{"bold":"To \u201cthrow\u201d a Thrown Artifact, put it on the bottom of your deck and use its ability. (Don't put anything on the bottom of your deck.)."]]}],"_id":"hnus0bjfC0PGoU5R","detailsOutput":"These are 13 cards that a player can \u201cthrow\u201d at the perfect moment. This means you \u201ccontrol\u201d that Artifact. At the end of your turn, when you discard all the cards you played that turn, the Artifacts you control stay in front of you for future turns and are not discarded.<ul><li><strong>To \u201cthrow\u201d a Thrown Artifact, put it on the bottom of your deck and use its ability. <\/strong><\/li><li>You can throw it on the same turn that you play the Throw Artifact, or you can wait until a later turn.<\/li><li>If you use this when your deck has not many cards left, you might draw the Thrown Artifact again quite soon. {"id":16,"value":"riseofthelivingdead","label":"Rise of The Living Dead","cardTypes":[2,3,4,5],"details":[{"points":[["\u201cRise of the Living Dead\u201d means ",{"bold":"\u201cEach player checks the top card of their Victory Pile. If that card is a Villain with a \u2018Rise of the Living Dead\u2019 ability, that Villain reenters the city.\u201d"}],["A Villain that reenters the city this way follows the same rules as any other Villain entering the city: First check if a Villain is pushed out to Escape, and resolve any Escape effects. Then do any Ambush abilities for the arriving Villain."],[{"bold":"However, note that a Villain returning to the city because a \u201cRise of the Living Dead\u201d ability does NOT itself bring back additional Villains with its own Rise of the Living Dead ability \u2013 a single player does NOT do a chain reaction of many Villains returning at once."}," However, since each player is affected by Rise of the Living Dead, several Villains might still return when Rise of the Living Dead occurs \u2013 a maximum of one returning Villain per player. (This is a change from when this keyword appeared in ",{"italic":"Secret Wars"},", when chain reactions were allowed. This change affects the old ",{"italic":"Secret Wars"}," expansion cards too.)"],["When Rise of the Living Dead happens, it affects each player in order. The player whose turn it is resolves it first, including any potential Escapes, then any Ambush effects. When all of that is complete, then the next player in clockwise order resolves Rise of the Living Dead in the same way."],["So how do you stop Zombies from returning? By burying them deep! After fighting a Villain with Rise of the Living Dead, look for ways to put a card that ",{"bold":"doesn\u2019t "}," have Rise of the Living Dead on top of that zombie Villain, effectively \u2018burying it.\u2019 That way, the next time Rise of the Living Dead happens, nothing will return. You can do this by fighting a Villain that doesn\u2019t have Rise of the Living Dead or Mastermind Tactic or rescuing a Bystander. You can also \u201cSoulbind\u201d the Rise of the Living Dead card to bind the zombie\u2019s soul and prevent it from ever returning."],[{"bold":"Mastermind Tactics are never returned by Rise of the Living Dead."}," Zombie Scarlet Witch\u2019s Tactics say \u201c",{"bold":"\u201cFight"},": Before putting this Tactic in your Victory Pile, Rise of the Living Dead.\u201d This means that fighting any Tactic with Rise of the Living Dead can return other Rise of the Living Dead Villains to the city. However, the Mastermind Tactics themselves are never returned, even if the top card of your Victory Pile was a different Mastermind Tactic with Rise of the Living Dead."],["If you put a Villain with Bystanders into your Victory Pile, you choose the order that all those cards go into your Victory Pile. So if you fight a Rise of the Living Dead Villain that had Bystanders, it\u2019s smart to put the Bystanders on top."]]}],"_id":"kOvafKisAYOK14Yh","detailsOutput":"<ul><li>\u201cRise of the Living Dead\u201d means <strong>\u201cEach player checks the top card of their Victory Pile. If that card is a Villain with a \u2018Rise of the Living Dead\u2019 ability, that Villain reenters the city.\u201d<\/strong><\/li><li>A Villain that reenters the city this way follows the same rules as any other Villain entering the city: First check if a Villain is pushed out to Escape, and resolve any Escape effects. Then do any Ambush abilities for the arriving Villain.<\/li><li><strong>However, note that a Villain returning to the city because a \u201cRise of the Living Dead\u201d ability does NOT itself bring back additional Villains with its own Rise of the Living Dead ability \u2013 a single player does NOT do a chain reaction of many Villains returning at once.<\/strong> However, since each player is affected by Rise of the Living Dead, several Villains might still return when Rise of the Living Dead occurs \u2013 a maximum of one returning Villain per player. (This is a change from when this keyword appeared in Secret Wars, when chain reactions were allowed. This change affects the old Secret Wars expansion cards too.)<\/li><li>When Rise of the Living Dead happens, it affects each player in order. The player whose turn it is resolves it first, including any potential Escapes, then any Ambush effects. When all of that is complete, then the next player in clockwise order resolves Rise of the Living Dead in the same way.<\/li><li>So how do you stop Zombies from returning? By burying them deep! After fighting a Villain with Rise of the Living Dead, look for ways to put a card that <strong>doesn\u2019t <\/strong> have Rise of the Living Dead on top of that zombie Villain, effectively \u2018burying it.\u2019 That way, the next time Rise of the Living Dead happens, nothing will return. You can do this by fighting a Villain that doesn\u2019t have Rise of the Living Dead or Mastermind Tactic or rescuing a Bystander. You can also \u201cSoulbind\u201d the Rise of the Living Dead card to bind the zombie\u2019s soul and prevent it from ever returning.<\/li><li><strong>Mastermind Tactics are never returned by Rise of the Living Dead.<\/strong> Zombie Scarlet Witch\u2019s Tactics say \u201c<strong>\u201cFight<\/strong>: Before putting this Tactic in your Victory Pile, Rise of the Living Dead.\u201d This means that fighting any Tactic with Rise of the Living Dead can return other Rise of the Living Dead Villains to the city. However, the Mastermind Tactics themselves are never returned, even if the top card of your Victory Pile was a different Mastermind Tactic with Rise of the Living Dead.<\/li><li>If you put a Villain with Bystanders into your Victory Pile, you choose the order that all those cards go into your Victory Pile. So if you fight a Rise of the Living Dead Villain that had Bystanders, it\u2019s smart to put the Bystanders on top.<\/li><\/ul>"}

{"id":94,"value":"heist","label":"Heist","cardTypes":[1,4,5],"details":[["Scott Lang's elaborate Heists are highlights of the movies, represented by this new keyword:"],{"points":[["Some cards say things like \u201cHeist: You get ",{"bold":"+2"},{"icon":2},"\u201c."],["Once per turn, if you have played any Heroes with Heist abilities (and\/or fought any Enemies with Heist abilities) you may \u201cattempt a Heist.\u201c"],["To do this, first assemble your crew: ",{"bold":"Count the number of different non-zero costs you have among all your Heroes this turn. This is your Heist Count."}," Then try to outfox the guards: ",{"bold":"Reveal the top card of the Villain Deck and check its printed VP."}],[{"bold":"If your Heist Count is higher"}," than that VP: The Heist worked! Use all Heist effects of Heroes you played and Enemies you fought this turn, in any order."],[{"bold":"If your Heist Count is tied"}," with that VP: It all went sideways, and you barely escaped! No effects."],[{"bold":"If your Heist Count is lower"}," than that VP: Your crew got caught! You gain a Wound (& no Heist effects)."],["You can only ever attempt one Heist per turn, no matter the outcome. If you succeed in the Heist, do all of the Heist effects before moving on to playing more Heroes or recruiting or fighting anything else. After your one Heist attempt for the turn, if you draw additional cards with Heist abilities (or fight additional Enemies. with Heist abilities), it will be too late to get those additional Heist effects."],["Heist checks for printed cost, so 4* and 4 count as the same cost."],["You don't have to go on a Heist. Weigh it carefully!"]]}],"_id":"mI8BjMM78k73oaAk","detailsOutput":"Scott Lang's elaborate Heists are highlights of the movies, represented by this new keyword:
  • Some cards say things like \u201cHeist: You get +2<\/strong>\u201c.<\/li>
  • Once per turn, if you have played any Heroes with Heist abilities (and\/or fought any Enemies with Heist abilities) you may \u201cattempt a Heist.\u201c<\/li>
  • To do this, first assemble your crew: Count the number of different non-zero costs you have among all your Heroes this turn. This is your Heist Count.<\/strong> Then try to outfox the guards: Reveal the top card of the Villain Deck and check its printed VP.<\/strong><\/li>
  • If your Heist Count is higher<\/strong> than that VP: The Heist worked! Use all Heist effects of Heroes you played and Enemies you fought this turn, in any order.<\/li>
  • If your Heist Count is tied<\/strong> with that VP: It all went sideways, and you barely escaped! No effects.<\/li>
  • If your Heist Count is lower<\/strong> than that VP: Your crew got caught! You gain a Wound (& no Heist effects).<\/li>
  • You can only ever attempt one Heist per turn, no matter the outcome. If you succeed in the Heist, do all of the Heist effects before moving on to playing more Heroes or recruiting or fighting anything else. After your one Heist attempt for the turn, if you draw additional cards with Heist abilities (or fight additional Enemies. with Heist abilities), it will be too late to get those additional Heist effects.<\/li>
  • Heist checks for printed cost, so 4* and 4 count as the same cost.<\/li>
  • You don't have to go on a Heist. Weigh it carefully!<\/li><\/ul>"}

If so, you don\u2019t discard that card and that player doesn\u2019t play a copy of it."],["If you are playing with the Final Showdown, you can\u2019t Coordinate during that Showdown."]]}],"_id":"njlJFwtHGktyfX2T","detailsOutput":"This keyword represents how Tony Stark and May Parker act as mentors to Spider-Man in the movie, helping him reach his full potential and become a true hero.Coordinating allows you to let another player \u201cborrow\u201d one of your cards.<\/strong> It is a critical way to help other players defeat tough enemies. During another player\u2019s turn, you can Coordinate with them like this:
  • Discard a Coordinate card from your hand and then draw a new card to replace it.<\/li>
  • That player can now play a copy of the card you coordinated with them. (A copy counts as playing the exact same card including its , , special abilities, and Hero Class symbol.)<\/li><\/ul>You can only Coordinate one card to each player on their turn. However, multiple players can each Coordinate one card to the player whose turn it is, in order to give that player a huge advantage.
    • If you are playing a solo game, once per turn, you may discard a card with Coordinate to draw a card.<\/li>
    • Coordinate is printed on cards in red text to make it easier to notice during other players\u2019 turns.<\/li><\/ul>There are a couple of things about Coordinate specific to Marvel Legendary\u00ae that don\u2019t apply to Legendary\u00ae Encounters:
      • When you offer to Coordinate a card to another player, that player can decline. If so, you don\u2019t discard that card and that player doesn\u2019t play a copy of it.<\/li>
      • If you are playing with the Final Showdown, you can\u2019t Coordinate during that Showdown.<\/li><\/ul>"}

  • Some Villains and Masterminds have the keyword \u201cDark Memories.\u201d This means \u201cThis gets +1<\/strong> for each Hero Class among cards in your discard pile.<\/strong>\u201d<\/li>
  • Likewise, some Hero cards also have \u201cDark Memories,\u201d. Playing a Hero card with this keyword gives you that same bonus: \u201cYou get +1<\/strong> for each Hero Class among cards in your discard pile.\u201d<\/li>
  • The Hero Classes are 4, 2, 1, 5, and 3, so Dark Memories can give anywhere from +0<\/strong> to +5<\/strong>. Grey cards like S.H.I.E.L.D. Agents don\u2019t have a Hero Class.<\/li>
  • It doesn\u2019t matter how many cards of a particular Hero Class you have in your discard pile. So if your discard pile were three 4 cards, four 2 cards, and five grey S.H.I.E.L.D. Agents, Dark Memories would give +2<\/strong>.<\/li>
  • Recruiting Heroes, 57, 10, and other discard abilities may increase the Dark Memories bonus.<\/li>
  • Likewise, if you draw or reveal enough cards that you have to shuffle your discard pile to make a new deck, the Dark Memories bonus will go back to +0<\/strong>. Time your plays and build your deck carefully to turn Dark Memories to your advantage!<\/li>
  • You can minimize the of The Hood and his gang by building a deck with very few Hero Classes. Or you can maximize the of Heroes with Dark Memories by recruiting many Hero Classes.<\/li>
  • \u201cDouble Dark Memories\u201d means double the bonus.<\/li><\/ul>"}

Ignore the special abilities and values on the currently face down side."]]}],"_id":"oBo3NvTL50ItdGaC","detailsOutput":"Transforming Heroes<\/strong>Duality and transformation are key themes of Hulk stories: the puny, brilliant scientist transforming into a raging monster. The \u201cTransform\u201d keyword highlights this theme.
  • Each Hero in this set has some special \u201cTransformed\u201d cards that go along with it. When you use these Heroes, don\u2019t<\/strong> shuffle their \u201cTransformed\u201d cards into the Hero Deck. Instead, set them aside in a special Transformation Pile. You can\u2019t recruit cards from this pile. Instead, you transform other cards into them.<\/li>
  • Some Hero cards like \u201cBruce Banner: Gamma Ray Experiments\u201d say things like \u201c...Transform this into Savage Hulk Unleashed.\u201d<\/li>
  • When you play a Hero card that says it transforms into another card, you complete all effects on the card you played and get its normal and .<\/li>
  • Then remove the transforming card from the game (putting it in the Transformation Pile) and put the newly transformed card into your hand instead (from the Transformation Pile). You can play the new Transformed card immediately that same turn.<\/li>
  • You still count as having played the transforming card you played and removed from the game, including effects like \u201cYou get +1<\/strong> for each 5 card you played this turn.\u201d But if an effect asks you to reveal one of your cards, you can only reveal the new, transformed card, not the old card that you removed from the game.<\/li>
  • Some transforming cards tell you to put the new card on top of your deck or in your discard pile instead.<\/li>
  • You can look through the Transformation Pile at any time.<\/li>
  • At the end of the game, store a Hero\u2019s Transformed cards with the rest of that Hero\u2019s cards. To start a game, you only need to bring out the Transformed cards for the Heroes you\u2019re using. Don\u2019t bring out all the Transformed cards in the entire game.<\/li>
  • If you sleeve your cards, you can put the Transformed version of the card in the same sleeve, behind the Transforming card. When it\u2019s time to transform, you just pull the back card to the front of the sleeve. It\u2019s a little thicker in the sleeve, but it still shuffles well.<\/li><\/ul>Transforming Masterminds<\/strong>Each Mastermind in this set is a double-sided \u201cTransforming Mastermind\u201d that transforms back and forth between two forms during the game.
    • The side with the \u201cAlways Leads\u201d ability starts face up.<\/li>
    • When a Master Strike or Mastermind Tactic ability occurs, it will tell you to \u201cTransform\u201d the Mastermind, meaning flip it over to its other side. (Don\u2019t also do the Master Strike ability of the new side.)<\/li>
    • A Mastermind only uses the abilities and of its currently face up side. Ignore the special abilities and values on the currently face down side.<\/li><\/ul>"}

  • Keep one card of the Combined Villain tucked under the other, so you can see both cards\u2019 and text.<\/li>
  • Since a Combined Villain has the text of both its Villain cards, it can get extra or restrictions from various special abilities on either of its cards. It also counts as both cards\u2019 Villain Groups.<\/li>
  • Symbiote Bonds never combine more than two Villains in the same city space. Ignore any effect that would combine a third Villain in that space.<\/li>
  • Once two Villains are bonded, only fighting can break them up. Other Symbiote Bonds abilities can\u2019t break up a Combined Villain to attach one of the cards to something else.<\/li>
  • If a Symbiote Bonds ability puts a new Villain card into the city from the Villain Deck, Escape Pile, Victory Pile, etc., do any Ambush ability on the newly entering card. However, that Ambush ability won\u2019t be able to break up a Combined Villain or add a third card to it.<\/li>
  • If a special ability automatically \u201cdefeats\u201d a Combined Villain, you still put just one of its cards into your Victory Pile and do that card\u2019s Fight effect.<\/li>
  • A combined Villain has the VP of both its cards combined. So you can spend Piercing Energy (from Legendary \u00ae: X-Men) equal to both cards\u2019 total combined VP to fight the Combined Villain, putting one of its cards into your Victory Pile as normal.<\/li><\/ul>"}

Furious rage drives them to seek more of the red delight, gaining strength from every kind of blood they drain. This is shown by the new Blood Frenzy keyword.
  • Blood Frenzy on a Hero card means \u201cYou get +1<\/strong> for each different VP value you have among cards in your Victory Pile.\u201d<\/strong><\/li>
  • Likewise on a Villain card, during your turn Blood Frenzy means \u201cThis Villain gets +1<\/strong> for each different VP value you have among cards in your Victory Pile.\u201d<\/strong><\/li>
  • (VP means \u201cVictory Points,\u201d shown as 4<\/strong>.)<\/li>
  • It only matters how many different VP values you have among cards in your Victory Pile. It doesn't matter how many you have of any single value. So if your Victory Pile has cards worth 0, 1, 1, 1, 2, 2, and 5 VP, then Blood Frenzy would give +4<\/strong>.<\/li>
  • This includes Bystanders in your Victory Pile. Horrifically, even heroic Vampires and Werewolves cannot always resist draining blood from innocents!<\/li>
  • Use whatever VP a card is worth, not just its printed VP. If a Master Strike becomes \u201ca Villain worth 4VP,\u201d then it counts as 4VP for Blood Frenzy. An \u201cUndercover\u201d Agent worth 1VP counts as 1VP too.<\/li>
  • If a card gets into your Victory Pile somehow with no printed or specified VP value, it counts as \u201c0 VP,\u201d which is a number that can help your Blood Frenzy.<\/li><\/ul>"}

"],["Whether that player gained a Wound or not, they then gain the Demonic Bargain\u2019s listed benefit."],["Some cards have you choose which player must make a Bargain for a benefit. Think carefully about how many cards in your deck cost 0. If most of your deck is still 0-cost cards, it may be worthwhile to seize the power of the Demonic Bargain for yourself. But if your deck has lots of high-cost cards, then it may be wiser to choose another player to make the Demonic Bargain instead. Just beware: mortals who think they can outwit and outbargain a Demon are often left regretting their hubris."],["When you choose a player to make a Demonic Bargain, that player cannot decline."],["Dormammu can force players to make cruel, all-downside Demonic Bargains, with the chance of a Wound plus an additional negative effect."],["If you use card abilities to look at or manipulate the top card of your deck, you may gain valuable insight as to whether a Demonic Bargain will punish you."]]}],"_id":"wbWSNAyAusx6wNqh","detailsOutput":"Demons offer gifts of power with a dark price, hoping to corrupt the souls of mortals. These deals with the devil are especially corrupting to the powerful and arrogant. The humble are more likely to escape with their souls intact. This is represented with the Demonic Bargain keyword.<ul><li>Some Villains like Satana Hellstrom say things like \u201cFight: Choose a player to make a Demonic Bargain with Satana Hellstrom to rescue three Bystanders.\u201d<\/li><li><strong>That player discards the top card of their deck to see if they are corrupted by power. If that discarded card costs 1 or more, that player is too powerful and arrogant to resist temptation and gains a Wound, to the demon\u2019s delight.<\/strong><\/li><li>If that discarded card costs 0, then that player has been humble enough to resist corruption. <\/li><li>Whether that player gained a Wound or not, they then gain the Demonic Bargain\u2019s listed benefit.<\/li><li>Some cards have you choose which player must make a Bargain for a benefit. Think carefully about how many cards in your deck cost 0. If most of your deck is still 0-cost cards, it may be worthwhile to seize the power of the Demonic Bargain for yourself. But if your deck has lots of high-cost cards, then it may be wiser to choose another player to make the Demonic Bargain instead. Just beware: mortals who think they can outwit and outbargain a Demon are often left regretting their hubris.<\/li><li>When you choose a player to make a Demonic Bargain, that player cannot decline.<\/li><li>Dormammu can force players to make cruel, all-downside Demonic Bargains, with the chance of a Wound plus an additional negative effect.<\/li><li>If you use card abilities to look at or manipulate the top card of your deck, you may gain valuable insight as to whether a Demonic Bargain will punish you.<\/li><\/ul>"}
